The formation of a solid within a solution, often by the combination of cations and anions to form an insoluble ionic compound.
The extent of agreement among several experimental values; reproducibility of results.
Force per unit area; in gases arising from the force exerted by collisions of gas molecules with the wall of the container.
The sequence of amino acids that defines a protein.
A substance produced by a chemical reaction.
A biological polymer of amino acids joined by peptide bonds.
The positively charged particle in an atomic nucleus; its mass is similar to the mass of a hydrogen atom.

A reaction in which the concentrations of all but one reactant are more than 10 times larger than the one reactant of interest; because there is appreciable change in only the one reactant concentration, the reaction rate appears to depend directly upon the concentration of only the low-concentration reactant.
Igniting spontaneously when exposed to air.
One of a set of numbers that specifies the state of an electron in an atom; the set of quantum numbers summarize results from quantum mechanics.
The manner in which the major subunits, each consisting of a separate polypeptide chain, of a large protein are joined together.
A symbol used to represent an unspecified group of atoms in an organic compound.
A mixture of equal amounts of enantiomers.
A unit of the energy absorbed by tissue from exposure to radiation; equal to 10<sup>-2</sup> J/kg; short for Radiation Absorbed Dose.
Describes a substance that gives off radiation‐alpha particles, beta particles, or gamma rays‐by the disintegration of its nucleus.
The release of particles and/or energy from an unstable nucleus.
A sequence of spontaneous nuclear reactions ending in the formation of a stable nucleus.
The process of measuring the amount of carbon-14 remaining in an organic material and from the measurement calculating the age of the material.
The temperature scale that uses as its zero point the absolute zero of the temperature scale and that has degrees the same size as the Fahrenheit scale.

The statement that the partial pressure of a gaseous substance in equilibrium with a solution in which that substane is a component is equal to the mole fraction of the substance in the solution times the vapor pressure of the pure substance.
One of the lanthanides; sometimes also includes scandium and yttrium.

In a differential rate equation, the proportionality constant that relates the rate with the concentrations of reactants and other species that affect the rate. The rate constant is the rate of reaction when all concentrations are 1 M.

An equation that describes the rate of a reaction as a function of the rate constant and the concentrations of reactants (and any other substances that affect the rate, such as products or catalysts); also called rate law.

An equation which describes the rate of a reaction as a function of the rate constant and the concentrations of reactants (and any other substances that affect the rate, such as products or catalysts); also called rate equation.
The step in a reaction mechanism that by its relatively slow rate limits the overall rate of a reaction; also called rate-limiting step.
The step in a reaction mechanism that by its relatively slow rate limits the overall rate of a reaction; also called rate-determining step.
A substance consumed by a chemical reaction.
The set of elementary steps by which a reaction is thought to occur; each individual step corresponds to either a bimolecular collision or unimolecular reaction of a single molecule.
An oxidation-reduction reaction; the term "redox" is obtained from the first few letters of "reduction" and "oxidation."
A chemical species that donates electrons in order to reduce another species. In the process the reducing agent is itself oxidized.
A sugar that reacts with silver(I) (Tollens test) or copper(II) (Fehling or Benedict tests) in a test for available aldehyde groups.
That part of a chemical reaction in which a reactant gains electrons; simultaneous oxidation of a reactant must occur.
In electrochemistry, an electrode whose constant potential can be compared with an unknown electrode potential to determine the latter.

In spectroscopy, a solution containing all components except the absorbing species of interest. For example, if one wanted to measure the concentration of iodine in the solvent heptane, one would use a reference solution which contained only pure heptane. Iodine, the species which absorbs light, should NOT be present.
The ratio of the partial pressure of water in the atmosphere to the equilibrium vapor pressure of water at the same temperature.
A unit of radiation that takes into account the biological effectiveness of the radiation; short for Roentgen Equivalent in Man.
An element in the region of the periodic table where the s and p atomic orbitals are being filled; also called main-group element.

A situation that arises when two or more Lewis structures can be drawn to represent covalent bonding in an ion or molecule. In each Lewis structure the atomic nuclei remain in the same positions; only the electrons move. When resonance applies, bonding is considered to be an average superposition of the individual Lewis structures.

Any of two or more Lewis structures that represent covalent bonding in an ion or molecule where the positions of the atomic nuclei remain the same. No single resonance structure represents the actualy bonding; rather the bonding is an average superposition of the individual Lewis structures.
A biological polymer, derived from nucleotide monomers, that is involved in protein synthesis. Abbreviated RNA.
Abbreviation for ribonucleic acid; a biological polymer of nucleotides that is involved in protein synthesis.
Heating in the presence of air or oxygen; most commonly used in converting natural metal sulfide ores to oxides as first step in recovery of the metal from its ore.
A tough, elastic polymer obtained from the juices of certain tropical plants; a synthetic material having similar properties.
Columns 1 and 2 of the periodic table, containing elements in which the s atomic orbitals are being filled in the building-up process of deriving atomic electron configurations.
An ionic compound that can be formed by replacing the hydrogen ion of an acid with a different cation.
A connection that permits ions to pass but that restricts the flow of solution between the anode half cell and the cathode half cell in an electrochemical cell.
The base-catalyzed hydrolysis of an ester; often used in the context of hydrolyzing fats to make soap.
Describes 1) a solution that contains the equilibrium concentration of a solute, or 2) an organic compound that contains no double or triple bonds (such as an alkane).
A formal statement that any spontaneous (product-favored) process is accompanied by an increase in the entropy (dispersal of energy) of the universe.
A reaction for which the rate is directly proportional to the square of the concentration of one species or to the product of the concentrations of two species.
The folding of a protein into sheets and helices held in their shape primarily by hydrogen bonding.
A substance having an electrical conductivity intermediate between that of a metal and that of a non-metal and whose conductivity incresaes with increasing temperature.
A membrane that selectively permits some species to pass through while rejecting others; often one that permits solvent molecules to pass through, but not large molecules such as proteins.
The effect of (negatively charged) electrons close to a (positively charged) nucleus in diminishing the attractive force between the nucleus and other electrons in the atom. Also called screening.
The international system of units (Système International d'Unité) based on seven fundamental units: meter, kilogram, second, ampere, kelvin, candela, mole.

A bond in which the electron density is symmetrically distributed around the line connecting two atomic nuclei; can be formed by the overlap of an s orbital on one atom with any kind of orbital on another atom or by two p orbitals pointing toward each other.
Any of the digits in a value that are known with certainty; all of the digits in a number correctly expressed in scientific notation.

One of two or more compounds having the same chemical composition but differing in the arrangement of the atoms (usually carbon atoms) forming the backbone of the structure of the compounds; also known as chain isomer.
Attraction between two atoms (nuclei and core electrons) that results from sharing a single pair of electrons between the atoms; a bond with bond order = 1.
A representation of the structure of a species in which lines are drawn to indicate the presence of bonds between atoms.

A component of a spectrophotometer that allows only a fraction of the incident light to pass through it; a slit can be used to select a narrow range of wavelengths from dispersed electromagnetic radiation.
A salt of a fatty acid produced by the saponification of fat.
Water from which high concentrations of cations having charge greater than +1 have been removed, usually by ion exchange.
A state of matter having a specific shape and volume and in which the particles do not readily change their relative positions.
The extent to which a solute dissolves in a solvent; often expressed as the mass of a substance that will dissolve in 100 mL of solvent.

The equilibrium constant expression for the dissolution of an electrolyte; the reactant is a solid and its concentration does not appear in the expression, which is a product of the concentrations of the products (raised the to appropriate powers).
Able to dissolve in a solvent to a significant extent.
The substance added to a solvent to make a solution.
A mixture of one or more substances dissolved in a solvent to give a homogeneous mixture.
The substance to which a solute is added to make a solution.
The quantity of heat energy transfer into a system required to raise the temperature of one gram of a substance by 1 K ( 1 °C). More correctly called specific heat capacity.
The quantity of heat energy transfer into a system required to raise the temperature of one gram of a substance by 1 K ( 1 °C). More correctly called specific heat capacity.
An ion present in a solution when a reaction occurs but which is not a reactant or product in the net ionic equation.
The arrangement of ligands in order by their influence on the electronic spectra of coordination complexes.
Capable of proceeding without an outside source of energy; refers to a reaction in which the products are thermodynamically favored (product-favored reaction).
The voltage attributed to a reduction half-reaction under standard conditions; its value is given referenced to the standard hydrogen electrode. Also called standard reduction potential.

The enthalpy change when one mole of a compound is produced from its elements, each in their most stable form at a given temperature and standard pressure (1 bar). Also called standard heat of formation.
The entropy of one mole of an element or compound at a given temperature and standard pressure (1 bar).
The change in Gibbs energy when one mole of a compound is produced from its elements, each in their most stable form at a given temperature and standard pressure (1 bar).
The voltage attributed to a reduction half-reaction under standard conditions; its value is given referenced to the standard hydrogen electrode. Also called standard electrode potential.
A system in which hydrogen (hydronium) ions and gaseous hydrogen are present in their standard states; used as a reference (of zero) for the values of standard reduction potentials.
A chemical procedure to accurately determine the concentration of a solute in a solution.
One of two or more compounds that have the same chemical composition and have the same atoms bonded to other atoms, but that differ in the spatial arrangements of the atoms.

The number that precedes the formula of a species in a balanced chemical equation; gives the relative number of chemical formula units or the relative chemical amount (moles) of each species that is consumed or formed.
The relationship among the amounts of reactants and products in a chemical reaction.
An acid that ionizes completely in a particular solvent.
A base that dissociates completely or ionizes completely in a particular solvent.
A representation of the structure of a species that indicates the arrangement of the atoms in space and the bonds between atoms.
The process of vapor forming from a solid without the intermediate formation of a liquid.
A material that is either an element or that has a fixed ratio of elements in its chemical formula.
A reaction in which one atom or functional group is replaced by another (distinguished from an addition reaction).
The molecule or ion that is a reactant in an enzyme-catalyzed reaction.
A small carbohydrate that either contains five or six carbon atoms or is a dimer of two units, each containing five or six carbon atoms.
The ability of certain substances at low temperatures to have zero resistance to the conductance of electricity.
Describes a solution that has a greater concentration of a solute than under equilibrium conditions.

The resistance to an increase in the area of a surface; due to the combined effect of adhesive and cohesive forces at the surface of a liquid. Defined as the energy required to increase the surface area of the liquid isothermally by one square meter.

In polymer chemistry, having regularly alternating structural units. For example, syndiotactic polypropylene has each methyl group along the polymer chain oriented in the opposite way to the methyl groups before and after it.
Formation of substances with more complicated sturctures than do their precursors.
A combustible mixture of hydrogen and carbon monoxide produced by passing steam over red hot coke. It is also known as water gas.
Describes a substance that has been manufactured‐one that has not been created by natural processes.
A physical property that indicates whether one object can transfer thermal energy to another object.
In a reaction mechanism, an elementary step in which three species collide.
A compound containing three elements.

The manner in which the sheets and helices of the secondary structure of a protein fold on themselves to define the three-dimensional structure; tertoaru structure is maintained by hydrogen bonds, dipole forces, ionic attractions, covalent bonds, and, most importantly, hydrophobic interactions.
The maximum quantity of a product that could be formed in a chemical reaction if all the limiting reactant reacted to form products (distinguished from actual yield).
The ability of a substance to transfer energy by heating another substance.
The study of the quantity of heat transferred into or out of a chemical system during a chemical reaction.
The study of the conversion of energy from one form to another and the availability of energy to do work.
A formal statement that at the absolute zero of temperature the value of the entropy of a perfect crystal is equal to zero.
The gradual addition of one solution to another until the chemical amount of one reactant being added matches stoichiometrically the amount of another reactant in the solution initially present.
A graph showing the progress of a titration; for example, a plot of pH or electrical conductivity versus volume of solution added.
A unit of pressure equal to 1 mm Hg or 1/760 atm.

Describes the relationship between two atoms or groups of atoms, each attached to one of two doubly bonded carbon atoms and located on the opposite side of the double bond. Also refers to groups located opposite to each other in an octahedral or square planar coordination complex.
The RNA that brings the correct amino acid to a ribosome where it is attached to a growing protein, abbreviated tRNA.

One of the elements in columns 3 through 12 of the periodic table, the region in the periodic table where d atomic orbitals are being filled in the building-up process for deriving atomic electron configurations; sometimes the elements in column 12 are not included.

One of the elements in columns 3 through 12 of the periodic table, the region in the periodic table where d atomic orbitals are being filled in the building-up process for deriving atomic electron configurations; sometimes the elements in column 12 are not included.
The fraction of incident light that passes through a sample.
One of the elements appearing after uranium in the periodic table; that is, an element with atomic number greater than 92.
A molecule that is an ester of glycerol and three fatty acids.
A molecular shape having the central atom surrounded by a plane of 3 atoms at the corners of a triangle, one atom above the plane, and one atom below.
Attraction between two atoms (nuclei and core electrons) that results from sharing of three pairs of electrons between the atoms; a bond with bond order = 3.
The temperature and pressure at which the solid, liquid, and vapor of a substance are in equilibrium with each other.
The isotope of hydrogen that has two neutrons in its nucleus.
Abbreviation for transfer RNA; the RNA that brings the correct amino acid to a ribosome where it is attached to a growing protein.

The statement that, for most liquids, the enthalpy of vaporization divided by the boiling temperature (in kelvins) has a nearly constant value of 75 to 80 J K<sup>-1</sup> mol<sup>-1</sup>; that is, the entropy of vaporization of a liquid is approximately constant.
This lamp is used to generate white light (containing all wavelengths visible to the eye) in spectrophotometers.

The idea that there is a theoretical limit on the accuracy with which the position and momentum of a particle can be determined simultaneously; the product of the experimental uncertainty in the position times the uncertainty in the momentum must be greater than Planck's constant divided by 4π.

An elementary step in a reaction mechanism in which a single molecule reacts to form products; formally no species collide in such a step, but the energy needed to overcome an activation barrier is provided to the single molecule through prior collisions.
A particular measure of a physical quantity that is used to express the magnitude of the physical quantity; for example, the meter is the unit of the physical quantity, length.

A small portion of a crystal lattice that by repetition can generate the entire lattice; the unit cell contains the same ratio of atoms or ions that is contained in a macroscopic sample of a substance.
Describes 1) a solution that contains less than the equilibrium concentration of a solute, or 2) an organic compound containing double or triple bonds.
The theory that describes covalent bonding in terms of the overlap of atomic orbitals on pairs of atoms; each bond is localized between two atoms and usually consists of one or more electron pairs.
In a neutral atom, any of the electrons found in the highest occupied shell as well as any electrons in incompletely filled subshells of lower shells.

A means of predicting the structures of simple ions and molecules, or of individual atoms in more complex molecules or ions, by counting the number of pairs of electrons in the valence shell of a central atom.

An equation that describes the behavior of gases and takes into account the effects of non-ideal behavior such as the non-negligible size of molecules of gas and forces of attraction between the molecules.
Attractive forces between polar or non-polar molecules, but not including hydrogen bonding.
The gaseous state of a substance that typically exists as a liquid or solid; a gas at a temperature near or below the boiling point of the corresponding liquid.
The pressure (or partial pressure) exerted by the gaseous form of a substance in equilibrium with the liquid form.
The formation of a vapor from a liquid; evaporation or boiling.
The resistance of a liquid to flow when subjected to shear stress.
An electrochemical cell in which a spontaneous reaction occurs. Such a cell can be used to generate electricity. Also called Galvanic cell.

Abbreviation for valence-shell electron-pair repulsion theory; a means of predicting the structures of simple ions and molecules, and single atoms in more complex molecules or ions, by counting the number of pairs of electrons in the valence shell of a central atom.
A process for increasing the strength and hardness of rubber by heating the rubber in the presence of sulfur.
The distance between the crests of adjacent waves (or between any adjacent corresponding points in waves); used in the context of electromagnetic radiation.
An acid that ionizes only partially in a given solvent.
An base that ionizes only partially in a given solvent.
A measure of the gravitational force on an object; directly proportional to mass.
A mechanical process in which energy is transferred to or from an object, changing the state of motion of the object.
A high-energy form of electromagnetic radiation that has sufficient energy to ionize inner electrons from an atom.
A reaction for which the rate of reaction is independent of the concentration of reactants.
